{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox Union |name= ADLV |country= [[Vatican City]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]] |members= |full_name= Association of Vatican Lay Workers |native_name= Associazione Dipendenti Laici Vaticani |image= |founded= 1985 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= |people= |website= |footnotes= }}<!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> The '''Association of Vatican Lay Workers''' ({{lang-it|Associazione Dipendenti Laici Vaticani}}; ADLV) is the sole [[trade union]] in [[Vatican City]]. It represents the majority of the 3,000 employees who work in the city state, making the Vatican the world's most unionized country.
The ADLV was formed in 1985 and was recognized by the Vatican authorities in 1993. The first ever strike in the Vatican was organized by the ADLV in 1988.
The ADLV is affiliated to the [[International Trade Union Confederation]].
==See also== {{Portal|Organized labour}} *[[Index of Vatican City-related articles]]
==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }}

revision.text:
The border between [[China]] and [[Nepal]] is {{convert|1414|km|mi}} in length, along the mountain range [[the Himalayas]], extends northwest-southeast direction, separating the south of [[Tibet Autonomous Region]] of [[China]] and the territory of [[Nepal]]. This border passes through the highest peak in the world, [[Mount Everest]]. The line extends between two [[tripoint]]s [[China]]–[[Nepal]]–[[India]]. The tripoint in the west is in the Nepalese district of [[Mahakali Zone]]. The tripoint in the east is in the region of [[Mechi]]. ==History== Throughout history, Nepalis traded with the Tibetans via the many border crossings. One of the most important goods traded was salt from the Tibetan areas.{{Cite magazine | title = A Himalayan Border Trilogy: The Political Economies of Transport Infrastructure and Disaster Relief between China and Nepal | first = Galen | author = Murton | magazine = Cross-Currents E-Journal | date = March 2016 | issn = 2158-9674 | accessdate = 2017-02-09 | url = https://cross-currents.berkeley.edu/e-journal/issue-18/murton | quote = }}{{Cite web | title = Nomads of Dolpo | last = Eede | first = Joanna | website = National Geographic Voices | publisher = [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] | date = 2015-06-12 | accessdate = 2017-02-10 | url = http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2015/07/12/nomads-of-dolpo/ | quote = }} The border between Nepal and China is one of the most natural boundaries of the earth, due to the barrier [[Himalayas]].{{cn|date=February 2017}} [[People's Republic of China]] and [[Kingdom of Nepal]] had a brief border dispute shortly before 1960.{{Cite web | title = International Boundary Study - China – Nepal Boundary | author = Office of the Geographer | date = 1969-05-30 | accessdate = 2017-02-14 | publisher = [[Bureau of Intelligence and Research]] | url = http://www.law.fsu.edu/library/collection/LimitsinSeas/IBS050.pdf | archive-date = 2012-05-03 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120503141259/http://www.law.fsu.edu/library/collection/LimitsinSeas/IBS050.pdf | language = | quote = The exact number of territorial disputes has never been ascertained, but as many as 20 sectors may have been involved. The most serious disputes were located at Rasu (north of Katmandu), Kimathanka in the east, Nara Pass, Tingribode near Mustang, Mount Everest, and the Nelu River. Most of these disputes were settled in favor of Nepal, although several favored China. }} They resolved this by officially signing border agreement in 1961.{{cite wikisource |title=中华人民共和国和尼泊尔王国边界条约 |trans_title=China-Nepal Border Agreement|wslanguage=zh|date=1961-10-05}} ==Border crossings== In 2012, Nepal and China agreed to open new [[port of entry|ports of entry]], to a total of 6 official ports. Three of the ports are designated as international ports, while three others are only designated for bilateral trade.{{Cite web | title = 中华人民共和国政府和尼泊尔政府关于边境口岸及其管理制度的协定 | trans-title = China-Nepal Agreement on Port of Entry | author = | publisher = Chinese Embassy in Nepal | date = 2012-01-14 | accessdate = 2017-02-10 | url = http://np.chineseembassy.org/chn/zngxs/zywj/t1059642.htm | language = zh | quote = }} The border crossing between [[Zhangmu]] and [[Kodari]] on the [[Friendship Highway (China–Nepal)|Friendship Highway]] has been in operation since 1968.{{Cite web | title = Nepal-China Seven Border Crossing-points | author = Buddhi Narayan Shrestha | work = Border Nepal Buddhi | date = 2015-11-29 | accessdate = 2017-02-09 | url = https://bordernepal.wordpress.com/2015/11/29/nepal-china-seven-border-crossing-points/ | quote = Kodari-Khasa has been in operation since 1968 for the transaction of trade and commerce. The second commercial border-point is the Rasuwagadhi-Kerung, which has come into use recently. }} In 2014, the border crossing at [[Rasuwa Fort]] (Rasuwagadhi) was opened for commerce. However, this crossing is not open to foreigners until 2017.{{Cite web | title = Tibet Nepal Border Closed | author = Lobsang | website = The Land of Snows | date = 2016-06-25 | accessdate = 2017-02-09 | url = http://www.thelandofsnows.com/tibet-nepal-overland-border-closed/ | quote = the new border crossing from Kyirong, Tibet to Rasuwaghadi, Nepal. Though this border crossing has NOT been opened to foreign travelers yet, this route has been open to traders from Nepal and China for much of the past year... }}{{cite web|last1=Tenphel|first1=Sonam|title=Gyirong Port, new Sino-Nepal Border Finally was Opened, so Lhasa and Kathmandu Overland Tour is all Available Now|url=https://www.tibettravel.org/news/gyirong-port-reopened.html|website=Tibet Vista|accessdate=26 November 2017}} In addition, this border crossing is being considered for a future rail crossing between the two countries.{{Cite web | title = China Wants To Stretch Rail Network All The Way To Touch Bihar: Report | author = | work = [[NDTV]] | date = 2016-05-24 | accessdate = 2017-02-09 | url = http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/china-wants-to-stretch-rail-network-all-the-way-to-touch-bihar-report-1409428 | language = | quote = A cross-border railroad link to the Rasuwagadhi area in Nepal has already been discussed between the two countries. }} Other crossings like the one at [[Burang Town|Burang]]-[[Hilsa, Nepal|Hilsa]] near the western tripoint while not widely accessible has been used for local trade between China and Nepal for many years.{{Cite web | title = Nepal, China rush to open Hilsa border | author = Prithvi Man Shrestha | author2 = Jaya Bahadur Rokaya | publisher = [[Kathmandu Post]] | date = 2016-03-24 | accessdate = 2017-02-10 | url = http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-03-24/nepal-china-rush-to-open-hilsa-border.html | quote = Hilsa is one of the six border points Nepal and China had agreed to open for international trade when former Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jibao visited Kathmandu in 2012. }} Some of those crossings has gotten so important for local trade that in 2008 when Chinese tightened its border control during the Olympics, villages like [[Kimathanka]] faced food shortages due to disruption of local trade.{{Cite web | title = China seals border, villages on Nepali side face starvation | first = Kishor | last = Budhathoki | work = The Himalayan Times | date = 2008-06-04 | accessdate = 2017-02-13 | url = https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/china-seals-border-villages-on-nepali-side-face-starvation/ | quote = Starvation looms large in the northern parts of Sankhuwasabha district after China closed the Kimathanka check post }} Historically, there are even more border crossings. The crossing at [[Kora La]] between [[Upper Mustang]] and [[Tibet]] for example was a major salt trade route. However, this crossing was closed due to Tibetan guerrillas in the 1960s. It remain closed for most of the year to this day, except when opening for limited local trade during the semiannual cross-border trade fairs. {| class="wikitable" |+ Ports of Entry According to 2012 Treaty |- !Treaty Name(Other Name) !Jurisdictions !Status !International

The '''Democratic Pacific Union''' is an international [[non-governmental organization]] which promotes political [[democracy]], strengthens maritime culture and marine technology, and replaces rigid, aggressive hegemony with the soft powers of love, peace, cooperation and sharing within the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The organization was established in [[Taipei]], [[Republic of China]] on August 14, 2005, and former [[President of the Republic of China|Vice President of the Republic of China]], [[Annette Lu]] is its current [[chairperson]]. ==Members== Member states are listed alphabetically by continent {|width=90% style="background:transparent" |-width=40% valign=top | '''[[Asia]]''' *{{flagicon|Taiwan}} [[Republic of China]] (Taiwan) *{{flagicon|India}} [[India]] *{{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Indonesia]] *{{flagicon|Japan}} [[Japan]] *{{flagicon|South Korea}} [[South Korea|Korea, Republic of]] *{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia]] *{{flagicon|Philippines}} [[Philippines]] *{{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russia]] *{{flagicon|Thailand}} [[Thailand]] *{{flagicon|East Timor}} [[East Timor|Timor-Leste]]
'''[[Americas]]''' *{{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canada]] *{{flagicon|Chile}} [[Chile]] *{{flagicon|Costa Rica}} [[Costa Rica]] *{{flagicon|Dominican Republic}} [[Dominican Republic]] *{{flagicon|El Salvador}} [[El Salvador]] *{{flagicon|Guatemala}} [[Guatemala]] *{{flagicon|Honduras}} [[Honduras]] *{{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Mexico]] *{{flagicon|Nicaragua}} [[Nicaragua]] *{{flagicon|Panama}} [[Panama]] *{{flagicon|Paraguay}} [[Paraguay]] *{{flagicon|Peru}} [[Peru]] *{{flagicon|United States}} [[United States]] |
'''[[Oceania]]''' *{{flagicon|Australia}} [[Australia]] [[File:Map of the Democratic Pacific Union.svg|thumb|450px|Democratic Pacific Union member states shown in green.]] *{{flagicon|Kiribati}} [[Kiribati]] *{{flagicon|Marshall Islands}} [[Marshall Islands]] *{{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[New Zealand]] *{{flagicon|Palau}} [[Palau]] *{{flagicon|Solomon Islands}} [[Solomon Islands]] *{{flagicon|Tuvalu}} [[Tuvalu]] |} ==References== * {{cite press release|url= http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/08/06/2003181902|title= Braving a storm to cross the new Strait|date= 2004-08-06|accessdate= 2008-05-18|publisher= [[Taipei Times]]}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061224015343/http://www.dpu.org.tw/ Official website] [[Category:Organizations established in 2005]] [[Category:International organizations based in China]] [[Category:International organizations of Asia]] {{int-org-stub}}

{{notability|date=May 2017}} [[File:Gent - Bisschop Eugène Van Rechem.jpg|thumb|Portrait.]] '''Eugène van Rechem''' (born 8 April 1858; died Ghent, 21 August 1943) was a Belgian auxiliary bishop of the [[Diocese of Ghent]].
During his career Rechem was [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] of [[St Bavo's Cathedral, Ghent]], and president of the major seminary in Ghent. He gained fame as president of the [[Sisters of Charity of Jesus and Mary]] and established missions in the Belgian Congo.
He was consecrated as a bishop in 1914 by [[Antoon Stillemans]].
His portrait is kept ins St Bavo's Cathedral.
== Honours == * '''1931''': commander in the [[Royal Order of the Lion]].<ref>RD 22.7.1931</ref>
{{authority control}} ==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Commanders of the Royal Order of the Lion]] [[Category:Belgian titular bishops]] [[Category:Canons (priests)]] [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1943 deaths]]

page.title: Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity

revision.comment: /* About the organization */ Delete criticism from non-RS source as undue
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} The '''Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity''' (GAPP ) is a [[nonprofit]] and [[nonpartisan]] membership organization founded on May 15, 2007 and based at [[Munich]], [[Germany]].
==Mission== The organization's mission is promoting understanding of [[globalization]] and informing the public about important global issues. A central aim of the organization, it states, is to “push decision makers towards reforms that create the conditions for a global [[society]] and global [[governance]].“<ref name="Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity">Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity. ''[http://www.globalapp.org/Global_Alliance_for_Peace_and_Prosperity_Support_Us.html About US.]''</ref>
The organization's first initiative is called ''Become a Global Citizen''. The initiative has its own website and it promotes global [[citizenship]]. The [[New York Times]] described the initiative “ a groundbreaking movement that empowers all citizens to participate in meaningful ways in the life of the community and the planet“.<ref>New York Times, ''Article Interconnected World of Today,October 6th 2007/International Part/Section A) Page 14.</ref>
==About the organization== From its inception the organization is nonpartisan, welcoming members from any political attitude and religious beliefs. However, its proceedings are almost universally private and confidential.<ref>Christopher Wright, ''The Elite Government'' (Appleton,II: Eastern Island Publishers, 2008) 77.</ref>
In July 2007 the organization was first mentioned by the British Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] when he called for a new international effort to achieve the [[Millennium Development Goals]]. He said that the “pace has been too slow and uncertain“ in meeting the promise made by world leaders seven years ago and that “we need more organizations like the Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity that push us for faster global reforms.“<ref>Speech of ''British Prime Minister Gordon Brown'' at the UN General Assembly at New York on July 31st 2007.</ref>
The organization was officially introduced at the international level at the [[Fabian Society]] New Year Conference in London in January 2008.
The current [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) is Christian Walz.
==Influence on foreign policy== In March 2008 the organization became the youngest [[non-governmental organization]] to join the [[United Nations Global Compact]] ( UNGC ) Program.<ref>[http://www.unglobalcompact.org/ParticipantsAndStakeholders/search_participant.html? ''Global Compact'', Local Non-Governmental Organizations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709180203/http://www.unglobalcompact.org/ParticipantsAndStakeholders/search_participant.html |date=2008-07-09 }}</ref>
The organization regularly attends conferences at [[European Union]] and the [[United Nations]]. Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity is a “breeding ground for important global policies“and it pushes “politicians, delegates of international organizations, public officials, the press, teachers, educaters and citizens towards having their part to play in the construction of a [[New world order (politics)|new world order]].“<ref>Die neue globale Bewegung ( Article in the German Frankfurter Rundschau Paper/February 7th, 2008/Politics Section/Page 21).</ref>
==See also== *[[Globalization]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.globalapp.org Global Alliance for Peace and Prosperity] – Organization website **[http://www.becomeaglobalcitizen.org Become a Global Citizen] – Initiative website *[http://www.unglobalcompact.org/participant/4349-Global-Alliance-for-Peace-and-Prosperity Global Compact] – UN website

revision.comment: date formats per [[MOS:DATEFORMAT]] by [[WP:MOSNUMscript|script]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox song | name = Go England | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = The England Boys | album = | released = 2002 | format = CD | recorded = | studio = [[Virgin Radio]] | venue = | genre = football song | length = | label = [[Mercury Records]] | composer = [[Paul Weller]] | lyricist = [[Daryl Denham]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} "'''Go England'''" is an English 2002 [[single (music)|single]] performed by [[The England Boys]]. It was written by the [[Virgin Radio]] DJ [[Daryl Denham]] and published by [[Mercury Records]] as an adaptation of [[The Jam]]'s 1980 "[[Going Underground]]" song to support the [[England national football team]] at the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name=b>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/team_pages/england/newsid_1950000/1950499.stm |title=Songs for the summer |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 April 2002 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=d>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/The-England-Boys-Go-England/release/1254492 |title=The England Boys - Go England (CD) |publisher=Discogs.com |date=25 May 2018 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> The song entered the British charts and reached a peak of 26 in the singles charts.<ref name=oc />
== History == "Going Underground" was written in 1980. The frontman of The Jam, [[Paul Weller]] had hoped that he could adapt his music to fit a football song to support the England national football team at the 2002 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nrk.no/kultur/fra-jam-undergrunn-til-fotball-vm-1.856393 |title=Fra Jam-undergrunn til fotball-VM |publisher=NRK |language=Norwegian |date=22 April 2002 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Weller gave permission to Daryl Denham to write new lyrics to adapt "''Going Underground''" into a football song in April 2002.<ref>{{cite web|author=Adam Sweeting |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2002/apr/26/shopping.artsfeatures |title=That was the modern world |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> "Go England" was created as a result and was performed by the England Boys, a band which comprised a number of Virgin Radio staff and presenters which was fronted by Denham.<ref name=ch>{{cite web|url=https://chart-watch.uk/index.php/archives/2002/week-ending-june-8th-2002 |title=Week ending June 8th 2002 |publisher=Chart Watch |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Graham |last=Betts |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Ewk5AQAAIAAJ&q=%22go+england%22+denham&dq=%22go+england%22+denham&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPgYju64zcAhWDV8AKHTUmBGEQ6AEIMzAC |title=Collins Complete UK Hit Singles 1952–2004|publisher=Collins |via=Google Books |date= |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> The song was intended to be used as the official fan's anthem for England at the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.intro.de/popmusik/gehoren-fussball-und-musik-zusammen |title=Gehören Fußball und Musik zusammen? |publisher=Intro.de |language=German |date=23 April 2002 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> However that commission from [[The Football Association]] went to "[[We're on the Ball]]" by [[Ant & Dec]].<ref name=ch />
== Release == "Go England" was released as a single in June 2002 with the CD release containing the original song as well as a commentary and karaoke mix.<ref name=d /> The song first entered the [[UK Singles Chart]] on 8 June 2002 at number 26 however it charted below competing football songs; "[[Hey! Baby#DJ Ötzi version|Hey! Baby]]" by [[DJ Ötzi]] and "[[Goldenballs (Mr Beckham to You)]]" by [[Bell & Spurling]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/entertainment/will-enjoys-second-uk-number-one-52952.html?utm_source=link&utm_medium=click&utm_campaign=nextandprev |title=Will enjoys second UK number one |work=Irish Examiner |date=2 June 2002 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> The following two weeks it fell to numbers 46 and 52 before exiting the charts after three weeks.<ref name=oc>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/search/singles/go-england/ |title=Go England |publisher=Officialcharts.com |date= |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TStOJCS7dB4 The official music video]

page.title: Grevenmacher (Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg constituency)

revision.comment: re-categorisation per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]], replaced: Category:History of Luxembourg (1815–1890) → Category:History of Luxembourg (1815–90) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The constituency '''Grevenmacher''' elected members to [[Luxembourg]]'s national [[legislature]], the [[Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg|Chamber of Deputies]], from 1848 until its abolition in 1919. It was coterminous with the [[Cantons of Luxembourg|canton]] of [[Grevenmacher (canton)|Grevenmacher]], in the east of the country.
After its abolition, it was replaced by [[Est (Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg constituency)|Est]], which covered the whole of the [[Grevenmacher District|District of Grevenmacher]], which also included the cantons of [[Echternach (canton)|Echternach]] and [[Remich (canton)|Remich]].
Members elected to represent Grevenmacher include [[François Altwies]] (1911–19), [[Joseph Bech]] (1914–19), and [[Auguste Metz]] (1848–54).
[[Category:Grevenmacher (canton)|Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg constituency]] [[Category:Defunct Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg constituencies]] [[Category:History of Luxembourg (1815–90)]] [[Category:History of Luxembourg (1890–1945)]] [[Category:1848 establishments in Luxembourg]] [[Category:1919 disestablishments in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Constituencies established in 1848]] [[Category:Constituencies disestablished in 1919]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = In My Cabana | cover = Margaret_-_In_My_Cabana.jpeg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Margaret (singer)|Margaret]] | album = | released = 10 February 2018 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = 2017 | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = 2:52 | label = [[Warner Music Sweden]] | writer = {{hlist|[[Anderz Wrethov]]|[[Linnea Deb]]|[[Arash (singer)|Arash Labaf]]|[[Robert Uhlmann (composer)|Robert Uhlmann]]}} | producer = {{Hlist|Anderz Wrethov|Linnea Deb|Arash Labaf|Robert Uhlmann}} | prev_title = [[Byle jak]] | prev_year = 2017 | next_title = Lollipop | next_year = 2018 }} "'''In My Cabana'''" is a song recorded by Polish singer [[Margaret (singer)|Margaret]]. It was written by [[Anderz Wrethov]], [[Linnea Deb]], [[Arash (singer)|Arash Labaf]], and [[Robert Uhlmann (composer)|Robert Uhlmann]].{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2018/02/10/sweden-samir-viktor-liamoo-melodifestivalen-2018/|title=Sweden: Samir & Viktor and LIAMOO Qualify to Melodifestivalen 2018 Final|last=Herbert|first=Emily|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=10 February 2017}} The song was released for digital download on 10 February 2018. "In My Cabana" peaked at number three on the [[Polish Music Charts#Singles charts|Polish Airplay Chart]] and number eight on the [[Sverigetopplistan|Swedish Singles Chart]]. Margaret participated with the song in ''[[Melodifestivalen 2018]]'', and qualified to ''Andra Chansen'' from the second semi-final on 10 February 2018. She subsequently progressed to the final and finished in seventh place with 103 points. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/in-my-cabana/1343829278?i=1343829279|title=In My Cabana – Single by Margaret|publisher=[[iTunes]] (US)|accessdate=17 February 2018}} | title1 = In My Cabana | length1 = 2:52 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! Chart (2018) ! Peak
position |- {{single chart|Poland|3|chartid=2667|year=2018|rowheader=true|accessdate=23 April 2018}} |- ! scope="row" | Poland ([[Polish Music Charts|Polish Airplay New]]){{cite web|url=http://bestsellery.zpav.pl/airplays/pozostale/archiwum.php?year=2018&typ=nowosci&idlisty=2604#title|title=AirPlay Nowości: 17.02. – 23.02.2018|publisher=[[Polish Society of the Phonographic Industry|ZPAV]]|language=Polish|accessdate=7 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307181447/http://bestsellery.zpav.pl/airplays/pozostale/archiwum.php?year=2018&typ=nowosci&idlisty=2604|archivedate=7 March 2018}} | 2 |- {{single chart|Sweden|8|artist=Margaret|song=In My Cabana|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |} ==Release history== {| class=wikitable ! Region ! Date ! Format ! revision.text:
{{Unsourced|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox character |name = Jenab Khan
{{lang-fa|جناب خان}} |series = [[Khandevane]] |image = |caption = |first = 2014 |last1 = |title = |publisher = |year = |last = |creator = Mohammad Bahrani |portrayer = Mehdi Borgheyee, Hamed Zabihi |voice = Mohamad Bahrani |alias = |species = }} '''Jenab Khan''' ({{lang-fa|جناب خان}}) is an [[Iranian culture|Iranian]] fictional [[puppet]] [[Fictional character|character]] in [[IRIB Nasim]] night show ''[[Khandevane]]'' hosted by [[Rambod Javan]]. Jenab Khan is voiced by [[Mohammad Bahrani]] and performed by Mehdi Borgheyee and Hamed Zabihi. == Characteristics and personality == He is best known for his funny character, [[Abadan, Iran|Abadanian]] accent and singing south Iranian songs. He also claims to be the owner of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]]. 35-year-old Jenab Khan loves a girl named Ahlam and has proposed to her on a regular basis since he was 20 years old. His friends are Behnam, Abood and Emad. Neither Ahlam nor his friends weren't shown in the show. == Appearances and subsequent controversy == He first appeared in a video channel program for kids, ''Kooche Morvarid'', ([[Persian language|Persian]]: کوچه مروارید - "The Pearl Alley") as an [[Abadan]]ian [[Laboo]] seller, then joined the 2nd season of the [[IRIB Nasim]] night show, ''[[Khandevane]]''. He was then abandoned from the show in December 2016, a day before launching the fourth season, due to objections of Saeed Salarzehi, director of ''Kooche Morvarid'', who claimed that the puppet was a property of the original series and has been used illegally. However, he is returning in fifth season due to his rights are bought by [[IRIB]]. == Sources == == External links == [[Category:Puppets]] {{Puppet-stub}} {{Iran-tv-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}}
Many places throughout [[North America|North]], [[Central America|Central]], and [[South America]] take their names from the languages of the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous inhabitants of the area]]. The following list, organized by country, includes settlements, geographic features, and political subdivisions whose names are derived from indigenous languages.
==Argentina== *See [[List of Mapudungun placenames|list of Mapudungun placenames]] for the respective placenames in Argentina
*[[San Fernando del Valle de Catamarca|Catamarca]] *[[Chubut Province]] *[[Curuzú Cuatiá]] *[[Machagai]] *[[Paraná, Entre Ríos|Paraná]] *[[Puerto Iguazú]] *[[Quilmes]] *[[Tucumán Province]] *[[Ushuaia]]
==Bolivia== *[[Cochabamba]] *[[Copacabana, Bolivia|Copacabana]] *[[Guayaramerín]] *[[Oruro, Bolivia|Oruro]] *[[Samaipata, Bolivia|Samaipata]] *[[Uyuni]] *[[Yacuíba]]
==Brazil== {{main|List of Brazil state name etymologies}}
===Alagoas State=== *[[Arapiraca]] *[[Maceió]]
===Ceará State=== *[[Iguatu]] *[[Maracanaú]] *[[Maranguape]] *[[Pacatuba, Ceará|Pacatuba]]
===Minas Gerais State=== *[[Araxá]] *[[Paracatu, Minas Gerais|Paracatu]]
===Pará State=== *[[Abaetetuba]] *[[Igarapé-Açu]] *[[Igarapé-Miri]] *[[Itaituba]]
===Paraná State=== *[[Apucarana]] *[[Curitiba]] *[[Guarapuava]] *[[Paranaguá]] *[[Umuarama]]
===Pernambuco State=== *[[Caruaru]]
===Rio de Janeiro State=== *[[Araruama]] *[[Guanabara Bay]] *[[Niterói]] *[[Nova Iguaçu]] *[[Paraty]] *[[Piraí]]
===Santa Catarina State=== *[[Itajai]]
===São Paulo State=== *[[Araçariguama]] *[[Araçatuba]] *[[Araraquara]] *[[Araras]] *[[Caraguatatuba]] *[[Jaguariúna]] *[[Piracicaba]] *[[Ubatuba]]
==Canada== {{main|List of place names in Canada of aboriginal origin}} [[Canada]] itself is a name derived from a [[Laurentian language|Laurentian Iroquois]] word meaning "village"<ref>{{cite book | first = Bruce G. |last = Trigger |author2=Pendergast, James F. | year = 1978 |chapter=Saint-Lawrence Iroquoians | title = Handbook of North American Indians Volume 15 | location= Washington |publisher= Smithsonian Institution | pages= 357–361 | id = OCLC 58762737}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first = Alan | last = Rayburn | year = 2001 | title = Naming Canada: stories about Canadian place names | edition = 2nd | isbn= 0-8020-8293-9 | publisher = University of Toronto Press | location= Toronto | pages = 13}}</ref> (c.f. [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] ''kaná:ta’'').<ref>Bright (2004:78)</ref><ref>{{cite book |first= Marianne |last=Mithun |year=1999 |title=The Languages of Native North America |isbn=0-521-29875-X |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=312}}</ref> See [[Canada's name]] for more details. Aboriginal names are widespread in Canada - for a full listing see [[List of place names in Canada of aboriginal origin]]. Those listed here are only well-known, important or otherwise notable places.
===Province and territory names=== {{main|Canadian provincial name etymologies}} *[[Ontario]] *[[Quebec]] - from [[Mi'kmaq language|Míkmaq]] ''kepék'', "strait, narrows"<ref>Afable, Patricia O. and Madison S. Beeler (1996). "Place Names". In "Languages", ed. Ives Goddard. Vol. 17 of ''Handbook of North American Indians'', ed. William C. Sturtevant. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, pg. 191</ref> *[[Manitoba]] *[[Saskatchewan]] *[[Nunavut]] *[[Yukon]]
===British Columbia=== NB Too many settlements, lakes, rivers, mountains and other items in British Columbia have indiegenous names for all of them to be included here. Only major or relatively notable items are listed.
====Regions==== *[[Chilcotin District|Chilcotin]] *[[Cariboo]] *[[Okanagan]] *[[Kootenays|Kootenay]] *[[Lillooet Country]] *[[Nicola Country]] *[[Stikine Country]] *[[Nechako Country]] *[[Cowichan Valley]] *[[Shuswap Country]] *[[Omineca Country]] *[[Atlin Country]] *[[Slocan Valley]] *[[Haida Gwaii]]
====Cities and towns==== *[[Nanaimo]] *[[Chilliwack, British Columbia|Chilliwack]] *[[Coquitlam]] *[[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]] *[[Qualicum Beach]] *[[Saanich, British Columbia|Saanich]] *[[Sooke]] *[[Ucluelet]] *[[Kitimat]] *[[Keremeos]] *[[Spuzzum]] *[[Bella Coola, British Columbia|Bella Coola]] *[[Bella Bella, British Columbia|Bella Bella]] *[[Kamloops, British Columbia|Kamloops]] *[[Sicamous, British Columbia|Sicamous]] *[[Osoyoos, British Columbia|Osoyoos]] *[[Skookumchuck, British Columbia|Skookumchuck]] *[[Lillooet, British Columbia|Lillooet]] *[[Penticton]] *[[Kelowna]] and [[West Kelowna]] *[[Spallumcheen, British Columbia|Spallumcheen]] *[[Malakwa]] *[[Slocan City]] <!--to be cont.-->
====Rivers and lakes==== *[[Chilcotin River]] **[[Chilko Lake]], [[Chilko River]], [[Taseko River]] *[[Omineca River]] *[[Kechika River]] *[[Lillooet River]] *[[Okanagan Lake]] & [[Okanogan River|Okanagan River]] *[[Similkameen River]] *[[Skeena River]] *[[Nass River]] *[[Homathko River]] *[[Nechako River]] *[[Squamish River]] *[[Klinaklini River]] *[[Stikine River]] *[[Alsek River]] *[[Tatshenshini River]] *[[Tagish Lake]] *[[Atlin Lake]] *[[Taku River]] *[[Cheakamus River]] *[[Elaho River]] *[[Nimpkish River]] *[[Somass River]] <!--to be cont.-->
====Mountain ranges==== *[[Shulaps Range]] *[[Cayoosh Range]] *[[Lillooet Ranges]] *[[Chilcotin Ranges]] *[[Stikine Ranges]] *[[Cassiar Mountains]] *[[Cariboo Mountains]] *[[Kitimat Ranges]] *[[Omineca Mountains]] *[[Muskwa Ranges]]
===Alberta=== *[[Kananaskis Country|Kananaskis]] *[[Athabasca, Alberta|Athabasca]] *[[Wetaskiwin]] - from the Cree word wītaskīwin-ispatinaw (ᐑᑕᐢᑮᐏᐣ ᐃᐢᐸᑎᓇᐤ), meaning "the hills where peace was made". <!--to be cont.-->
===Saskatchewan=== *[[Saskatoon]] - from [[Cree language|Cree]] ''misāskwatōmin'', "[[saskatoon berry]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Saskatoon |title=Saskatoon |publisher=[[Dictionary.com]] |accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref>
Manitou Lake http://www.canadianbucketlist.com/experiences/manitou/ http://www.britannica.com/topic/manitou-North-American-Indian-religion
===Manitoba=== *[[Winnipeg]]—a transcription of a western Cree word meaning "muddy waters" *[[Manitoba]] -- "where the spirit (manitou) speaks"
===Ontario=== ** [[Adjala–Tosorontio|Adjala-Tosorontio]]:''Tosorontio'' is derived from the [[Wyandot language|Huron (Wyandot)]] word meaning "beautiful mountain", and ''Adjala'' was the name of the wife of Chief [[Tecumseh]]. ** [[Algonquin Provincial Park]]: Named after the [[Algonquin people|Algonquin]] ([[Anishinaabe|Anishinaabeg]]) people of Ontario. ** [[Almaguin Highlands]]: Derived from the words ''Algonquin'' and ''Magnetawan''. ** [[Assiginack]] ** [[Algoma District]] ** [[Atikokan]]: [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] for "caribou bones." ** [[Attawapiskat, Ontario|Attawapiskat]]: "People of the parting of the rocks" from the [[Swampy Cree language|Swampy Cree (Omushkegowuk)]] ''chat-a-wa-pis-shkag''. ** [[Brantford, Ontario|Brantford]]: Named after [[Joseph Brant]], a [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]] leader. ** [[Cataraqui River]] ** [[Cayuga, Ontario|Cayuga]]: Named for the [[Cayuga people]] of Ontario. ** [[Chinguacousy Township, Ontario|Chinguacousy]] ** [[Lake Couchiching|Couchiching]]: Derived from the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''gojijiing'', meaning "inlet." ** [[Deseronto]]: Named for [[John Deseronto|Captain John Deseronto]], a native [[Mohawk people|Mohawk]] leader who was a captain in the British Military Forces during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. ** [[Guelph/Eramosa|Eramosa]]: Thought to be derived from the word ''un-ne-mo-sah'' (possibly meaning "black dog", "dead dog", or simply "dog"). ** [[Esquesing Township]]: [[Mississaugas|Mississauga]] [[Anishinaabe]] word ''ishkwessin'', meaning "that which lies at the end", which was the original name for [[Bronte Creek]]. ** [[Etobicoke]]: "The place where the [[Alder|alders]] grow" from the word ''wadoopikaang'' in the [[Ojibwe language]]. ** [[Fort Erie, Ontario|Fort Erie]]: [[Iroquoian languages|Iroquoian]], ''erige'', meaning "cat". ** [[Gananoque, Ontario|Gananoque]]: Origin unknown, thought to be derived from Native languages for "place of health" or "meeting place" or "water running over rocks." ** [[East Garafraxa|Garafraxa]]: Possibly derived from the word for "panther country". ** [[Iroquois Falls]]: Named for the [[Iroquois|Iroquois people]] of Ontario. ** [[Kakabeka Falls]]: From the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word ''gakaabikaa'', "waterfall over a cliff". ** [[Kaministiquia River]]: Derived from ''gaa-ministigweyaa'', an [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word meaning "(river) with islands". ** [[Kanata, Ontario|Kanata]]: [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] word meaning "village" or "settlement." ** [[Kapuskasing]]: Of [[Cree language|Cree]] origin, possibly meaning "bend in river." ** [[Kawartha Lakes]]: An Anglicization of the word ''ka-wa-tha'' (from ''ka-wa-tae-gum-maug'' or ''gaa-waategamaag''), a word coined in 1895 by Martha Whetung of the [[Curve Lake First Nation]], meaning "land of reflections" in the [[Anishinaabe]] language. The word was subsequently changed by tourism promoters to ''Kawartha'', with the meaning "bright waters and happy lands." ** [[Kenora|Keewatin]]: [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] for "north wind." Derived from either ''kīwēhtin'' in [[Cree language|Cree]] or ''giiwedin'' in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. ** [[Greater Madawaska, Ontario|Madawaska]]: Named after an [[Algonquin people|Algonquian]] band of the region known as ''Matouweskarini'', meaning "people of the shallows". ** [[Magnetawan]]: Derived from the word for "swiftly flowing river." ** [[Manitoulin Island]]: ''Manitoulin'' is the [[English language|English]] version, via [[French language|French]], of the Old [[Ottawa dialect|Odawa]] name ''Manidoowaaling'', which means "cave of the spirit". ** [[Manitouwadge, Ontario|Manitouwadge]]: From ''manidoowaazh'' in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]], meaning "cave of the spirit." ** [[Assiginack|Manitowaning]] ** [[Manotick]]: Derived from [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] for "island." ** [[Matachewan, Ontario|Matachewan]] ** [[Matawatchan, Ontario|Matawatchan]] ** [[Mattawa, Ontario|Mattawa]]: "Meeting of the waters" in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. ** [[M'Chigeeng, Ontario|M'Chigeeng]] ** [[Michipicoten, Ontario|Michipicoten]]: "Big bluffs" in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. ** [[Missinaibi River|Missinaibi Provincial Park]]: [[Cree language|Cree]] for "pictured waters," thought to refer to the pictographs found on rock faces along the river. ** [[Mississauga]]: Named for the native tribe of the [[Mississaugas]] ** [[Mississippi Mills, Ontario|Mississippi Mills]]: May originate from ''Mazinaa[bikinigan]-ziibi'', [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] for "[painted] image river", referring to the pictographs found on [[Mazinaw Lake]]. ** [[Moosonee]]: Derived from the [[Cree language|Cree]] word ''moosoneek'', meaning "at the [[Moose River (Ontario)|Moose (River)]]". ** [[District Municipality of Muskoka|Muskoka]]: Named for a First Nations chief of the 1850s, Chief Yellowhead or ''Mesqua Ukie''. ** [[Greater Napanee|Napanee]] ** [[Nassagaweya Township, Ontario|Nassagaweya]]: Derived from the [[Mississaugas|Mississauga]] word ''nazhesahgewayyong'', meaning "river with two outlets." ** [[Neebing, Ontario|Neebing]] ** [[Niagara, Toronto|Niagara]]: [[Iroquois]] in origin, meaning uncertain. ** [[Nipigon, Ontario|Nipigon]]: May have originated from the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word ''animbiigoong'', meaning "at continuous water" or "at waters that extend [over the horizon]." ** [[Nipissing, Ontario|Nipissing]]: From the [[Anishinaabe language|Anishinaabe]] term ''nibiishing'', meaning "at (some) water". ** [[Nottawasaga River]]: Derived from the [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] words for "Iroquois" and "river outlet". ** [[Ohsweken, Ontario|Ohsweken]] ** [[Oneida Nation of the Thames]] ** [[Onondaga Township, Ontario|Onondaga]] ** [[Ontario]] ** [[Opasatika]], "river lined with poplars". ** [[Oshawa]]: from the [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] term ''aazhaway'', meaning "crossing to the other side of a river or lake" or just "(a)cross". ** [[Otonabee–South Monaghan|Otonabee]]: From the Ojibwe term "Odoonabii-ziibi" (Tullibee River). Otonabee comes from the words ode which means "heart" and odemgat that comes from "boiling water". It translates into "the river that beats like a heart in reference to the bubbling and boiling water of the rapids along the river" ** [[Ottawa]]: "To buy" from the word ''adaawe'' in the [[Anishinaabe language]]; adapted as the name of the [[Odawa people]]. ** [[Penetanguishene]]: believed to come from either the Wyandot language or from the Abenaki language via the Ojibwa language, meaning "land of the white rolling sands". ** [[Petawawa, Ontario|Petawawa]]: From Algonquin meaning "where one hears the noise of the water" ** [[Powassan]]: From the word for "bend." ** [[Pukaskwa National Park]] ** [[Saugeen Shores|Saugeen]]: Ojibwa language, Zaagiing, meaning outlet ** [[Shawanaga Township, Ontario|Shawanaga]] ** [[Scugog]]: Derived from the Mississauga word sigaog, which means "waves leap over a canoe." ** [[Shuniah, Ontario|Shuniah]]: named after the Ojibwa word "zhooniyaa" for "money" or "silver" ** [[Sioux Narrows-Nestor Falls|Sioux Narrows]] ** [[Sioux Lookout]] ** [[Tecumseh, Ontario|Tecumseh]] ** [[Tehkummah]] ** [[Temagami, Ontario|Temagami]]: from the [[Anishinaabe language|Anishinaabe]] word ''dimiigami'', "deep water(s)". ** [[Timiskaming (disambiguation)|Timiskaming]]: from the Algonquin language ''Temikami'' or ''Temikaming'', meaning "deep waters". ** [[Toronto]]: from an Iroquoian language, but of uncertain derivation. Another story says it is derived from the Mohawk word "tkaronto" meaning "trees standing in the water". ** [[Tuscarora Township, Ontario|Tuscarora]] ** [[Tyendinaga]]: Derived from a variant spelling of Mohawk leader Joseph Brant's traditional Mohawk name, Thayendanegea. ** [[Wahnapitae, Ontario|Wahnapitae]]: from the Anishinaabe ''waanabide'', "be shaped like a hollow tooth". ** [[Wasaga Beach]]: Derived from "Nottawasaga," as above. ** [[Wawa, Ontario|Wawa]] ** [[Ashfield–Colborne–Wawanosh|Wawanosh]] ** [[Wikwemikong, Ontario|Wikwemikong]]: from the Anishinaabe ''wiikwemikong'', "Bay of Beavers" from Nishnaabe word "Amik" meaning beaver. ** [[Plympton–Wyoming|Wyoming]]: derived from the Munsee name xwé:wamənk, meaning "at the big river flat."
===Quebec===
====Regions==== *[[Abitibi Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Abitibi]] *[[Kativik]] *[[Manicouagan Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Manicouagan]] *[[Nunavik]] <!--should maybe be in prov/terr list as is Qu. equiv. of Nunavut--> *[[Outaouais]] *[[Le Fjord-du-Saguenay Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Saguenay]] *[[Temiscamingue]] *[[Ungava (electoral district)|Ungava]]
====Towns and villages==== *[[Cascapédia]] *[[Chibougamau]] *[[Chicoutimi]] *[[Chisasibi]] *[[Hochelaga (village)|Hochelaga]] *[[Inukjuak, Quebec|Inukjuak]] *[[Ivujivik]] *[[Kahnawake]] *[[Kanesatake]] *[[Jonquière|Kenogami]] *[[Kuujjuaq]] *[[Matagami]] *[[La Matapédia Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Matapedia]] *[[Métabetchouan]] *[[Mistissini]] *[[Nemaska]] *[[Paspebiac]] *[[Puvirnituq]] *[[Salluit]] *[[Shawinigan]] *[[Shigawake]] *[[Stadacona]] *[[Tadoussac]]<!--might be fr?--> *[[Wemindji]]

==Chile== {{main|List of place names in Chile of Aboriginal origin}} *[[List of Mapudungun placenames]]
Non-Mapudungun Placenames: *[[Arica]] *[[Calama, Chile|Calama]] *[[Copiapó]] *[[Coquimbo]] *[[Coyhaique]] *[[Iquique]] *[[Pali-Aike National Park]] *[[Torres del Paine National Park]]
== Colombia == {{main|List of Muisca toponyms}} * [[Arauca, Arauca|Arauca]] * [[Bogotá]] - from former main Muisca settlement [[Bacatá]] * [[Cali]] - from [[Calima culture|Calima]] * [[Cúcuta]] * [[Duitama]] - from [[Tundama]] * [[Ibagué]] - from [[Pijao people|Pijao]] ''cacique'' Ibagué * [[Maicao]] * [[Nemocón]] * [[Sogamoso]] - from Suamox * [[Tunja]] - from former Muisca settlement Hunza * [[Zipaquirá]] - [[Chibcha language|Muysccubun]]: "land of the ''zipa''" or "city of our father"
==Ecuador== *[[Ambato, Ecuador|Ambato]] *[[Babahoyo]] *[[Chimborazo]] *[[Cotopaxi]] *[[Guayaquil]] *[[Otavalo (city)|Otavalo]] *[[Quito]] *[[Tulcán]] *[[Tungurahua]]
==El Salvador== *[[Cojutepeque]] *[[Cuscatlán Department]] *[[Sensuntepeque]] *[[Usulután]] *[[Zacatecoluca, La Paz| Zacatecoluca]]
== [[Guatemala]] == The country name comes from [[Nahuatl language|Nahuatl]] ''Cuauhtēmallān'', "place of many trees", a translation of [[K'iche' language|K'iche']] ''K’ii’chee’'', "many trees" (="forest").<ref>Campbell (1997:378 n. 10)</ref> *[[Chichicastenango]] *[[Chimaltenango]] *[[Chiquimula]] *[[Escuintla]] *[[Huehuetenango]]- from Nahuatl, the original Mayan name was Xinabahul *[[Jalapa, Jalapa|Jalapa]] *[[Jutiapa]] *[[Lake Atitlán]] *[[Lake Petén Itzá]] *[[Mazatenango, Suchitepéquez|Mazatenango]] *[[Quetzaltenango]]- from Nahuatl, the original Mayan name was Xelajú *[[Zacapa]]
==Guyana== *[[Demerara]] *[[Kaieteur Falls]]
==Honduras== *[[Choluteca, Choluteca|Choluteca]] *[[Juticalpa, Olancho|Juticalpa]] *[[Nacaome]] *[[Siguatepeque]] *[[Tegucigalpa]]
==[[Mexico]]== The name of [[Mexico]] is the Nahuatl name for the island in the middle of [[Lake Texcoco]] where the Aztecs had their capital, its etymology is opaque.
===States=== *'''[[Chiapas]]'''- Believed to derive from the ancient city of Chiapan, which means "the place where the chia sage grows" in [[Náhuatl]]. *'''[[Chihuahua, Chihuahua|Chihuahua]]'''- May come from "dry place" in an unknown Indian language.<ref>Bright (2004:99)</ref> *'''[[Coahuila]]'''- possibly from the Nahuatl word Cuauhillan - "Place of trees" *'''[[Guanajuato]]'''- Means "hill of frogs" in the [[Purépecha language]] {{citation needed|date=July 2012}} *'''[[Michoacán]]'''- Translates to "the place of the fishermen" from the [[Nahuatl]] word ''michhuahcan''. *'''[[Nayarit]]'''- derived from the [[endonym]] of the [[Cora people]] "''naayarite''" *'''[[Oaxaca]]'''-Comes from the [[Nahuatl]] word ''huaxyácac'' or "place of the [[Lead tree|guaje trees]]". *'''[[Querétaro]]'''- Could come from the [[Otomi language|Otomi]] meaning "the great ball game"{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} or the [[Purépecha language]] meaning "place of stones".{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} *'''[[Tamaulipas]]'''- derives from ''tamaholipa'' a [[Huastec people|Huastec]] term that could mean "place where high hills". *'''[[Tlaxcala]]'''- Means "Place of Maize tortilla". in [[Nahuatl]] *'''[[Zacatecas]]'''- Named after the [[Zacatec]]; an indigenous nation in the area. It means "inhabitants of the grassland" in [[Nahuatl]].

revision.text:
{{Other uses of|Nikita|Nikita (disambiguation){{!}}Nikita}} [[File:Dmitrevsky nikita.jpg|thumb|A [[wood engraving]] of the legend of Nikita]]
'''Nikita the Tanner''', '''Nikita Kozhemyaka''' ({{lang-ru|Никита Кожемяка}}) or '''Mykyta Kozhumyaka''' ({{lang-ua|Мики́та Кожум'я́ка}}), is an [[East Slavs|East Slavic]] [[folk hero]] ([[bogatyr]]), a character from a legend. In some sources he is called ''Kyrylo the Tanner'' ({{lang-ua|Кирило Кожум'я́ка}}) ({{lang-ru|Кирилл Кожемяка}})<ref>[http://feb-web.ru/feb/skazki/texts/af0/af1/af1-432-.htm?cmd=0&hash=148 Народные русские сказки А. Н. Афанасьева]. Moscow: Nauka, Vol. 1 (1984). Notes</ref> or ''Elijah the Tailor'' ({{lang-ru|Илья Швец}}, {{lang-ua|Ілля Швець}}). The oldest prototype on it could be found in [[Laurentian Codex|Laurentian Chronicle]].
==The legend==
The [[fairy tale]] of Nikita tells that a dragon, [[Slavic dragon|Zmey Gorynych]], used to attack the lands of Rus and take beautiful girls as prisoners. One day he even kidnapped the daughter of the Kievan [[kniaz|prince]]. To find out the dragon's weakness, the woman pretended to fall in love him. Gorynych revealed her there's only one person in the world that can defeat him: a tanner from Kiev, Nikita. The princess told these news to her pigeon, who alerted her father, the prince. The prince went to the tanner's house to ask for help. It took the prince a while to persuade Nikita into fighting, and the bogatyr refused the wealth and power that the prince offered him. Eventually, the prince gathered hundreds of children in front of Nikita's house, and they begged the bogatyr to save them from Gorynych's attacks. Only then Nikita agreed to fight.
Nikita then went to Gorynych's lair, and, after a long earth-shattering fight, had the dragon heavily beaten with his heavy wooden club. Frightened, the dragon offered Nikita to become allies and rule the world together. Nikita demanded that they plow the border of their halves of the world, then used the dragon instead of a plowing horse. After they plowed the furrow across the whole world, Nikita demanded that they plow further to divide the sea as well. The foolish Gorynych obeyed and drowned in the ocean.
==In media== *''[[Kashchey the Immortal (film)|Kashchey the Immortal]]'' (1945), [[Sergei Stolyarov]] as Nikita. The film is loosely inspired by the legend and combines characters from various Russian folk tales. * ''Nikita Kozhemyaka'' (animated short film, 1965) - replaces the dragon with a nomadic horde. * ''Nikita Kozhemyaka'' (animated short, 2008) - an episode in the Mountain of Gems series of shorts, a relatively faithful, albeit comical, adaptation of the legend. * ''Nikita Kozhemyaka'' (animated feature film, 2016) - very loosely inspired by the legend; the main protagonist is Nikita's baby son.
==See also== *[[Simon the Tanner]] * [[Dobrynya Nikitich]]
==References== {{Commons category|Nikita Kozhemyaka}} {{Reflist}}
==Literature== *{{Cite book |last1=Warner |first1= Elizabeth |authorlink1= |title= Russian myths, illustrated |series= Legendary past |year= 2002 |publisher= British Museum |isbn= 9780714127439 |pages= 80}} *{{Cite book |last1=Haney |first1= Jack V. |title= Russian Wondertales: Tales of heroes and villains |year= 1999 |publisher= M.E. Sharpe |isbn= 9781563244896 |pages= 135}} * [http://www.ukrcenter.com/%D0%9B%D1%96%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B0/%D0%9E%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80-%D0%9E%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8C/39828-1/%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0-%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%83%D0%BC%D1%8F%D0%BA%D0%B0 A poem "Mykyta Kozhem'jaka" by Oleksandr Oles' (in Ukrainian)]
{{Slavic mythology}}

revision.text:
[[File:Relazione Michel Soriano.jpg|right|thumb|1560 Relazione of Michel Soriano, Ambassador to [[Philip II of Spain]], copy written about 1610]] '''Relazioni''' ([[Italian language|Italian]] for reports or accounts; ''singular'' '''relazione''') were the final reports presented by [[Venice|Venetian]] ambassadors of their service in foreign states. Relazioni contained descriptions of the current political, military, economic, and social conditions of the country visited. Relazioni are important to [[historians]] for recording the development of diplomacy in [[early modern Europe]].
== Background ==
"During the fourteenth, fifteenth, and sixteenth centuries, Italian states cultivated commercial, diplomatic, and political relations with first the Turkoman emirates of western Anatolia, and then the [[Ottomans]] (as well as other eastern Mediterranean states) as part of their multifaceted to maintain long - established trading empires and to keep the Ottoman armies out of the Italian peninsula."<ref>Goffman, Daniel. 2007. "Negotiating with the Renaissance State: The Ottoman Empire and the New Diplomacy." In The Early Modern Ottomans: Remapping the Empire. Eds. Virginia Aksan and Daniel Goffman. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 2007 p.62</ref> Out of all the Italian states, the Venetians and the state of Venice faced these threats the most directly because the Ottoman armies and navies began to push up and into the Adriatic seas. The military threat of the [[Ottoman Empire]] loomed large within Italian consciousness, but the government of the [[Republic of Venice]] knew that its [[commerce]] depended less and less on its own natives and armies and more and more on its good relations with the [[Ottoman Empire]]. As a result, this forced Venice to feel the need to an Ottoman world in the making because the [[Ottoman Empire]] had been expanding so rapidly at the time.
There were very many Venetian merchants that lived within the Ottoman Empire which made the state of Venice feel a need to protect their merchants in the "foreign" and "fearful" places under Ottoman rule. The Venetians sought to do so by appointing permanent representatives known as [[consuls]], better known as ambassadors, whose job was to shield their subjects in the "foreign" state and describe in frequent letters the happenings within the Ottoman state. This system is thought to have been the beginning of the development of modern [[diplomacy]] in Europe. Upon their return to the Venetian state, these permanent representatives would present the happenings that they witnessed within the Ottoman Empire to the Republic in a document known as relazione. Beginning in 1454, an appointed permanent representative always resided in the Ottoman State (usually in the Ottoman capital).
== Contents and the Significance Relazioni ==
"The Relazione provided a broad and comprehensive synthesis, periodically brought up to date by successive ambassadors, of the political military, economic, and social conditions of the country visited." <ref>Queller, Donald E. 1973. "The Development of Ambassadorial Relazioni." In Renaissance Venice. Ed. J. R. Hale. London: Faber and Faber p.175</ref> A fully developed Venetian relazione from the sixteenth century and later on in time was quite different from a final report on the procedures and outcome of a mission.
"The Ottoman precedent for such activities is nowhere better demonstrated than in the relazioni that Venetian consuls routinly delivered before the Senate upon recall from postings in the Ottoman capital. The goal of these reports was to contain the Turkish advance and to defend Venetian positions." <ref>Goffman, Daniel. 2007. "Negotiating with the Renaissance State: The Ottoman Empire and the New Diplomacy." In The Early Modern Ottomans: Remapping the Empire. Eds. Virginia Aksan and Daniel Goffman. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press p.71</ref> Relazioni gave Venetians the knowledge they needed to know about the enemy (the Ottomans). Relazioni were very significant to Venetians because they contained stress points and fault lines where the Ottoman Empire might weaken of its own account or where Venice might intervene. In simple terms they were significant to Venetians as they were like a "Strategy Guide" that the Venetians could turn to if they had to.
== The Popularity of Relazioni ==
"In the course of the sixteenth century the fame of the Venetian relazioni spread far and wide and copies were sold abroad at good prices, not only to governments, but also to erudite collectors." <ref>Queller, Donald E. 1973. "The Development of Ambassadorial Relazioni." In Renaissance Venice. Ed. J. R. Hale. London: Faber and Faber p. 176</ref> Venetian noble families kept their own copies of relazioni, especially those families by which a member of the family had brought honour upon the house. From these sources came the copies that are now in various libraries and archives. In the sixteenth century gained international popularity and concern for the security of the relazioni grew. Unless there became a control over the distribution of relazioni, the Venetians feared, "the ill effect of either sealing their envoys' lips or divulging to the public what ought to be kept a secret."<ref>Queller, Donald E. 1973. "The Development of Ambassadorial Relazioni." In Renaissance Venice. Ed. J. R. Hale. London: Faber and Faber p. 177</ref> Unfortunately for the Venetian government, the efforts to achieve security of the relazioni were never successful however, "it is the great good fortune of the modern historian, for to the scattered copies we owe many of the extant relazioni, especially the earliest."<ref>Queller, Donald E. 1973. "The Development of Ambassadorial Relazioni." In Renaissance Venice. Ed. J. R. Hale. London: Faber and Faber p. 177</ref>
== See also == *[[Italian Renaissance]] *[[Republic of Venice]]
== Further reading ==
Brummett, Palmira. 2007. "Imagining the Early Modern Ottoman Space, from World History to Piri Reis." In The Early Modern Ottomans: Remapping the Empire. Eds. Virginia Aksan and Daniel Goffman. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press p. 15 - 58
[http://userwww.sfsu.edu/~epf/1997/carman.html Carman, Elizabeth. 1997. "Diplomacy Through the Grapevine: Time, Distance, and Sixteenth-Century Ambassadorial Dispatches." Ex Post Facto 6.]
Wicquefort, Abraham de. 1716. The Embassador and His Functions To Which Is Added, an Historical Discourse, Concerning the Election of the Emperor and the Electors. Trans. John Digby. London: Printed for B. Lintott p. 253 - 256
== References ==
Goffman, Daniel. 2007. "Negotiating with the Renaissance State: The Ottoman Empire and the New Diplomacy." In The Early Modern Ottomans: Remapping the Empire. Eds. Virginia Aksan and Daniel Goffman. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press p. 61 - 74
Queller, Donald E. 1973. "The Development of Ambassadorial Relazioni." In Renaissance Venice. Ed. J. R. Hale. London: Faber and Faber p. 174 - 196
== Notes == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Italian Renaissance]] [[Category:Republic of Venice]] [[Category:Diplomacy]]

{{flagicon|Republic of the Congo}} [[Bernard Kolelas]] |commander2={{flagicon|Republic of the Congo}} [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]] |}} The '''Republic of the Congo Civil War''' was the first of two [[Ethnic conflict|ethnopolitical]] [[civil war|civil conflicts]] in the African state of [[Republic of the Congo]], beginning in 1993 and continuing until December 1994. [[Pascal Lissouba]] remained President until [[Republic of the Congo Civil War (1997–99)|another civil war in 1997]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{no footnotes|date=August 2015}} {{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/3dedffab4.html|title=Republic of Congo (Brazzaville): Information on the human rights situation and the Ninja militia|work=Resource Information Center|date=14 November 2000|accessdate=26 May 2015}} {{Republic of the Congo topics}} {{Years in the Republic of the Congo}} {{Post-Cold War African conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Republic Of The Congo Civil War}} [[Category:1993 in the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:1994 in the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:History of the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Wars involving Gabon]] [[Category:Wars involving the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Ethnicity-based civil wars]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1993]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1994]] [[Category:Political history of the Republic of the Congo]] {{RCongo-stub}}

The Rimphaces were a tribe of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] [[Nomad|Nomads]] who likely spoke a [[Sarmatians|Sarmatian]] language of the [[Scythians|Scythian]] family. They are mentioned by [[Pliny the Elder]] as living north of the [[Amazons]] and [[Hyperborea|Hyperboreans]], with the [[Cimmerians|Cimmeri]], [[Acae (Ancient People)|Acae]], [[Georgili (Ancient People)|Georgili]], [[Moschia|Moschi]], [[Cercetae]], [[Cissianti]], and [[Phoristae]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MRB5AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA94&lpg=PA94&dq=Cissianti&source=bl&ots=un1dAN0y9g&sig=PfjTUi71ppptTVWebGxE89hJ5J8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAkPr5wLbVAhVHs1QKHQQbD8oQ6AEIOjAE#v=onepage&q=Cissianti&f=false|title=Race and Ethnicity in the Classical World: An Anthology of Primary Sources in Translation|last=Kennedy|first=Rebecca F.|last2=Roy|first2=C. Sydnor|last3=Goldman|first3=Max L.|date=2013-09-01|publisher=Hackett Publishing|isbn=9781624660900|language=en}}</ref>

Updated in 2016, the station has two side platforms with two tracks. It is served by [[BG Voz]] and by ''Srbija Voz'' line 52 connecting Pančevo Vojlovica to Pančevački Most.[http://www.srbvoz.rs/kurir2017.pdf Srbija Voz 2017 schedule], pp 88-89, 92-95 {{link language|sr}} (retrieved 18 March 2017) The station is connected with the Belgrade public transit bus line 108.[http://www.gsp.rs/dnevne_linije.aspx GSP Beograd day lines] {{link language|sr}} (retrieved 18 March 2017) == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Railway stations in Belgrade]] {{Serbia-transport-stub}} {{Europe-railstation-stub}}
